Spotlight

Thai election results

The election was called in December after the coalition led by Anutin collapsed after just three months. Credits: Reuters

The what: PM Anutin Charnavirakul has claimed victory in Thailand‚Äôs snap general election. With about 90% of ballots counted, his conservative Bhumjaithai Party is projected to secure roughly 194 of 500 seats, far more than any other party but short of an outright majority. The reformist People‚Äôs Party fell to second with about 116 seats and signalled it would accept opposition if Anutin forms a coalition.

The factors: Anutin Charnavirakul‚Äôs victory stemmed from a mix of nationalism, organization, and electoral arithmetic. His Bhumjaithai Party harnessed patriotic sentiment after border tensions with Cambodia, presenting itself as the guardian of the monarchy and military. Populist economic pledges appealed to older and rural voters. Crucially, Anutin secured the backing of influential local figures, giving him a clear edge in constituency-based races.

The failure: The much-anticipated ‚Äúorange wave‚Äù behind the reformist People's Party failed to materialize because enthusiasm did not translate into votes. While the party retained strong urban and youth support, it struggled in provincial constituencies dominated by local patronage networks. Its reform-heavy agenda appealed to younger voters but resonated less with older and rural Thais, prioritizing immediate economic relief.

Manhunt ends

Summary: Russia extradites suspect in Moscow shooting of senior GRU official, underscoring rising security risks.

The what: Russian authorities say they have detained the suspected gunman who shot senior military officer Vladimir Alekseyev in Moscow. The suspected gunman, named Lyubomir Korba, was detained by police in the UAE before being extradited to Russia. A second suspect has been arrested in Moscow, while a suspected female accomplice is believed to have fled to Ukraine. Investigators say several suspects will be questioned and charged.

The background: Alekseyev is a senior Russian military intelligence officer and the Deputy Head of the GRU, one of Russia‚Äôs most secretive and powerful security agencies. He has played a central role in intelligence and covert operations linked to Ukraine, Syria, and Russia‚Äôs broader confrontation with the West. Alekseyev was awarded the Hero of Russia medal by Vladimir Putin.

The implications: The attack shows increasing security risks for Russia‚Äôs military leaders. It also fuels tensions as peace talks begin. Since Russia‚Äôs war in Ukraine in 2022, several senior Russian officers have been killed or targeted. Some attacks were claimed by Ukrainian military intelligence. However, Kyiv denies any involvement in this situation.
 
 

Worldwide

üáØüáµ Japan - Snap elections. Japan‚Äôs ruling Liberal Democratic Party is set to regain a majority in the lower house elections. This marks a big victory for ultraconservative PM Sanae Takaichi. She enjoys support from young people and projects a populist image. Her plans include fiscal stimulus and a stronger defense. A large mandate might allow constitutional changes (Iron lady prevails).

üá∏üá¶ Saudi Arabia - Invests in Syria. Saudi Arabia will invest heavily in post-war Syria. This includes a low-cost airline they will co-own, a $1B telecom project, and infrastructure deals for airports and water desalination. This shows Riyadh‚Äôs support for Syria‚Äôs Islamist-led government as Damascus works to rebuild its economy (shifting priorities).

üáµüáπ Portugal - Socialist bags run-off. Centre-left Socialist Ant√≥nio Jos√© Seguro clinched Portugal‚Äôs presidential runoff, defeating far-right populist Andr√© Ventura. With roughly 70% of ballots counted, Seguro led with about 64% of the vote to Ventura‚Äôs 36%. This vote tested support for Ventura‚Äôs Chega party amid instability from repeated elections and rising debates on immigration and populism (breaking the mold).

üá∏üá¥ Somalia - Slams Israel. Somalia‚Äôs president has condemned Israel‚Äôs recognition of Somaliland as illegal interference, warning against any Israeli military base in the breakaway region. Israel‚Äôs move, the first of its kind, has brought on regional tensions in the Horn of Africa and Red Sea, challenging Somalia‚Äôs territorial integrity and raising fears of further instability and geopolitical rivalry (concerns on the horn).

üáÆüáπ Italy- Protestors arrested. Protests in Milan disrupted the start of the Winter Olympics. Six people were arrested after clashes with police. Demonstrators criticized the Games for their costs, social impact, and environmental issues. Suspected sabotage on northern Italy‚Äôs railways also caused delays. Authorities defended the new security laws and labeled the unrest criminal (local grievances).

 

Foundations

Where is Abkhazia?

Prior to the separatist rebellion in the early 1990s led by ethnic Abkhaz, ethnic Georgians had made up almost half of Abkhazia‚Äôs population. Credits: GlobalPost

The what: Abkhazia is a breakaway region of Georgia that declared independence in 1992 after the collapse of the Soviet Union. It functions as a de facto independent state with its government and institutions. Abkhazia borders Russia to the north and Georgia‚Äôs Samegrelo region to the east and south. Only a handful of countries recognize it, including Russia and some of its historical allies, such as Syria, Venezuela, Nauru, and Nicaragua. The UN and the rest of the world legally recognize it as part of Georgia.

The history: Historically, Abkhazia lay at the crossroads of Greek, Byzantine, and Ottoman influence before being absorbed by the Russian Empire in the 19th century. Under Soviet rule, Abkhazia was first a separate republic, then, in 1931, downgraded to an autonomous republic within Georgia. As the Soviet Union disintegrated, conflict erupted between Abkhaz separatists and Georgian forces in 1992-93. With decisive backing from Russia, Abkhaz forces prevailed, leading to the mass displacement of ethnic Georgians.

On the ground: Abkhazia remains politically unstable, with frequent protests and leadership struggles. The economy is fragile, reliant on Russian subsidies, pensions, and tourism from southern Russia. Many ethnic Georgians displaced by the 1992-93 war have not returned, leaving deep demographic scars. Politically, local authorities operate independently but are closely aligned with Moscow

Last year, the country held elections after President Aslan Bzhania resigned following protests against a proposed funding agreement with Russia, which many locals viewed as threatening Abkhazia's autonomy. The region's future is uncertain, as it remains caught between its pursuit of sovereignty and reliance on Russia.
